abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Artisans Small and
            Medium Scale Enterprises Project for the Ivory Coast was
            unsuccessful. The project failed to achieve its objectives,
            institutional development was negligible, sustainability is
            unlikely, and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower
            was unsatisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, a more in-depth evaluation of the SME I
            project should have been carried out by the Bank to better
            assess the merits of a second line of credit. Second, the
            project should have been supported with additional SME
            sector work, not only to identify the inadequacies in the
            policy environment which contributed to the failure of the
            first SME loan but also the means to improve the
            effectiveness of institutions set-up to help SMEs. Third,
            successful implementation of any SME project requires an
            integrated package of financing and technical assistance to
            enterprises before and after they are launched. Fourth, a
            weak and poorly managed intermediary, such as CCI, required
            more intensive supervision. Also, more emphasis should have
            been placed on resource mobilization. Finally, the
            Government should have been quicker to act upon
            recommendations made by supervision missions.
